ygData.subject: Re: Discrete Neural Networks
ygData.msgSnippet: So it works?  I would think that the mutation paramaters would have to be biased (more chance of adding a node than normal NEAT).  Does that help?

So it works?  I would think that the mutation paramaters would have to be b=
iased (more chance of adding a node than normal NEAT).  Does that help?

--=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "torvhydda" <torvhydda@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Coo=
l idea!
> 
> I had to try it on my eco project. I gave them 1 bit for the b=
ias. 2 bits for the light angle, and 3 bits for each distance ray (6 rays t=
otal). They got 1 bit for the output thrust, and 1 bit for the output turn =
angle.
> So totally they have 21 inputs & 2 outputs. Each one just 1 bit.
>=
 
> The summation, in the activation function neat.c:_genome_activate(), is=
 replaced with NAND. If a node has only one input the node acts like a NOT.=

> The gene weights has no impact on anything in this test.
> 
> for (n =3D=
 0, res =3D 1; n < nin; n++, op++)
>  res =3D !(res && (*op->ptr =3D=3D 1))=
;
> 
> 
> In eco.c (LINE 30 - 39) one can experiment with how many bits eac=
h input & output has.
> 
> I uploaded eco-bnn.tar.gz, to the eco folder. It=
 contains win exe + 3 patches for the 0.6 src release.
> 
> They learn how =
to follow blue light, but it takes longer. Train them on an empty map for f=
aster sucess.
> 
> /Magnus
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "snapmedown" <=
snapmedown@> wrote:
> >
> > What are the thoughts on a neural network that =
has inputs and outputs digitized?  Perhaps 8 bits or even less?  This would=
 reduce the search space, but encourage larger structures.
